He did not rob Peter to pay Paul, but being an erstwhile advocate of the Irish language and a bilingual constitution, instead of robbing Peter to pay Paul he robbed Peter to pay Peadar instead, and so he gave to the farmer as a farmer and took from the farmer as a taxpayer.

He went further. As far as the small farmers are concerned he takes more back from them in the taxation on sugar alone than he gives in actual relief out of the £750,000. I think Deputy Davin quoted figures to prove this here to-day. The small farmer whose valuation was from £10 downwards comprises the big majority of the people working in this country. They will only get on an average from 10/- to 14/- relief in taxation out of this grant. And the same small farmer, with an average of from five to seven members in his household, will pay in sugar taxation an average of from 11/- to 16/- I have given a margin of from 10/- to 14/- in the relief that the small farmer will get, and from 11/- to 16/- in what he will have to pay in sugar. I have left the margin so wide because I think it is the fairest way to put it. There is one very definite thing, anyway, and that is, that the small farmer with a household of from five to seven members will pay actually more in sugar taxation than he will get in relief of rates.

On the question of the sugar taxation, of course, it was interesting to know what was the President's point of view on that matter. On Friday, in his little trashy speech, he attempted to tell us why the sugar taxation was imposed. His excuse was that even with the halfpenny per lb. addition sugar would be still cheaper than it was two years ago. That was rather an illuminating point of view from the President. If that is to be followed out to its logical conclusion such articles of food as are necessary for the poorer people to use should be kept up on as high a level as they were years ago by extra taxation. That would justify putting a tax on every other commodity of life which is reduced in price owing to production and would justify it being kept at a higher figure by taxation. Even with the tax sugar is still going to be cheaper than it was two years ago, and that satisfies the President.

He did not make any mention of the fact that the income tax is 1/6 lower to-day than it was a few years ago, and that not due to any world conditions either but due to the action of the President and the members of the Executive Council. They deliberately reduced the income tax by 1/6 in the £ lower than it was a few years ago, and they deliberately increased the price of sugar to the poor simply because world conditions have favoured them to the extent that sugar was coming down. Why not if he makes that argument about sugar make it also about the income tax? If he talks about sugar being still cheaper to the poor than it was two years ago he should take into account the fact that the rates in the County Mayo, even under the administration of the super Commissioner whom they have sent down to administer the affairs of the county, have increased by 3/11 for the past three years. And part of that increase, amounting to 8d. in the £, was imposed by the Commissioner sent down by the President. I would like the President of the Executive Council, when he comes to make his trashy little statement in the House for the purpose of rallying the weak members of his own Party, that he should consider other parts of the country beside the income tax payers in Dublin.

In the County Mayo under the Government scheme 13,364 holdings not exceeding £4 valuation will receive an aggregate share of the grant amounting to £7,100, which works out at 10/7 per holding. 7,639 holdings of a valuation exceeding £4 and not exceeding £7 will receive in the aggregate £8,800 or £1 3s. 0d. per holding. As against these two figures 12 landowners with holdings the valuation of which exceeds £300 will receive between them £1,310 or £109 3s. 4d. each; and 28 landowners with holdings exceeding £200 and not exceeding £300 in valuation will receive £1,420 or £50 14s. 0d. each. The average area of the small holdings in Mayo which do not exceed £4 in valuation works out at just over 15 acres, while the average area of the holdings between £4 and £7 valuation is about 24 acres.

The method in which he takes money out of one pocket of the farmer in order to put it into another by imposing a tax on sugar, is deplorable. There is also the very unfair method of distribution. The farmer who is worse off, who has to keep a large family, such as the small farmer in Mayo, and who is hardest hit by emigration being stopped is the man who is hardest hit by extra taxation. He has to cater for his family despite the obstacles put up by the Government, while the big farmer, who is not hit by the stoppage of emigration and who, as a rule, has a small family, is facilitated by the Minister in his Budget.

You have the very questionable attitude of the Minister in remitting the tax on betting. I would not mind the tax on racecourses being abolished, provided it would be some definite good for horse-breeding, but on the Minister's own admission it is going to do no good whatever to the horse trade or to the race meetings in this country. The Minister in his statement dealing with the remission of the betting tax, said: “I am quite satisfied that the tax did not do any serious direct injury to Irish racing, and that in itself it had only an inconsiderable psychological effect.” Those are the Minister's own words. If it is not going to do any injury to horse racing why this remission of tax amounting to £25,000? If any other members of the community came to the Minister and put up arguments about a certain tax being remitted, and if the Minister thought it was of no use, does anyone think he would remit it? There is something sinister behind the Minister's attitude in this matter. It is not that I object to the remission of this tax, if I thought it would do any good to horse breeding in this country, but the Minister says it will not. It is quite all right to give relief to the farming community, and it is quite all right to put on extra taxes, but we find that for this £750,000 which is to be given to the farmers, the farmers have got to pay an additional price. It is rather interesting from a Government point of view that when they want £300,000 extra in order to give this £750,000 to the farmers they must immediately go and tax the commodity which the poor use, sugar. They could not provide the money except by extra taxation. But we find that the Government, in the last financial year, provided £216,000 for army officers in gratuities and salaries without extra taxation. Not alone that, but they provided £216,000 for army officers without coming to this House at all for the money. Now they have immediately to go and tax the farmers' breakfast table to provide £300,000.

Here is an interesting sidelight on the policy of Cumann na nGaedheal. Not alone are they taxing the farmer for the relief they are giving him, but the farmer has to sacrifice his local authority. Whatever little power the farmers or the agricultural community had in local councils, they have got to give up those powers. Those councils have got to be scrapped. They have to pay this as an additional price for the relief of the agricultural community. It was no surprise to us that the Government policy was to quench out the local authorities and prevent their having any voice in the taxation of this State or in running this country economically. The Minister for Local Government has been doing that quite successfully for a long time, but not as successfully as the Government would wish. He was leaving a bad odour behind him. Now the Minister for Finance is going to quench out those local authorities and throw in at the same time the bribe of a little relief in rates. I do not believe the country will accept that. Members of this Party are not going to allow the Minister to pass off the bribe in that way. If local authorities are going to be abolished, if whatever little power farmers have is to be taken from them, it is not going to be taken without every possible opposition we can give in this House.

There was one undignified remark in the Minister for Finance's statement. He referred to members of the local bodies as a pack of wind-bags. It is quite all right for the Minister for Finance to say that. If he were a wise man he would realise that some of those whom he calls “windbags” have come into his own Party from local bodies. He would look at Deputy Sheehy, one of the local wind-bags down in Cork, and he would look at Deputy Davis, the ex-chairman of the Mayo County Council, who has come into his Party and is chairman of it. I do not like those slighting remarks about wind-bags on country councils. The members of the county councils might have their faults, but they have worked very hard and unselfishly. They have worked without remuneration. There was a time when the Minister for Finance and his Party depended very much on the wind-bags of the local councils. It is adding insult to injury now to address them as a pack of wind-bags. I think the Minister, in his closing statement, would be doing good to himself, his Party, and the country as a whole if he withdrew that statement.

Of course we are asked to pay a tribute to the Minister for Finance because of the wonderful work done in balancing the Budget. The President in his closing statement on Friday and again to-day paid that tribute and said that all of us, apart from politics, should be all good sheep for one day and go down on our knees to the Minister. On Friday he said “I should like to say, however, before closing now that Deputy O'Connell, Deputy Anthony and Deputy Nolan all paid a well-deserved tribute to the Minister for Finance in connection with his long and favourable record as Minister for Finance. Deputy Redmond was the first to notice it and he has perhaps this advantage over Deputies opposite that he has had experience of two representative institutions.” As to Deputy O'Connell's, Deputy Anthony's or Deputy Nolan's opinion of Mr. Blythe we do not mind. As to Deputy Redmond's opinion of Mr. Blythe or the President's opinion of Deputy Redmond we do not mind much either.

There was a time in the recent history of this House when any statement low, mean, or scornful was not bad enough for the President to address to Deputy Redmond. I read in the records of this House certain statements addressed by the President to Deputy Redmond not so many years ago. Evidenty Deputy Redmond has distingushed himself sufficiently of late years to become an object of the President's admiration. Because of Deputy Redmond's experience in two representative institutions his opinion is to be valued higher than the opinion of any other Deputy. We present the Deputy and his opinions to the President. I must say that the President is very often as much at error in his choice of company as he is mean in his choice of words. Deputy Nolan talked about the President of course and also about the Vice-President, who is Minister for Finance, and stated that if the Budget was introduced in any other Parliament there would be applause from every side of the House. The Deputy remarked that the Minister had balanced his Budget, that there was no deficit, and that the country was not bankrupt. Might I ask what did Cumann na nGaedheal Deputies expect?

Have the members on the Front Benches and the Minister for Finance been taking these Deputies into their counsels during the past year, telling them that the country is going bankrupt, and that we were “down and out,” or was it that Cumann na nGaedheal Deputies were realising that since the Government took office they have succeeded in piling up a debt of two millions every year? Is that what was troubling Cumann na nGaedheal Deputies? Were they troubled because the Government, since they came into office, have handed over to England, in round figures, £40,000,000, or were they perturbed that that could not go on or that the country would go bankrupt? Were these the worries that so troubled Deputy Nolan and other Deputies that they were terribly surprised to find that the Minister for Finance, in introducing his Budget, has shown that the State is not yet gone bankrupt? While our opinion of the Minister for Finance is not a good one, we realise that the country is not gone bankrupt, and that it is quite possible to introduce a Budget which is, to a certain extent, a balanced Budget, we realise that despite the financial bungling of the Minister for Finance the farmers through all these years have worked hard and have paid up.

If this country is not bankrupt, if the Budget is balanced, and if our credit is good at home and abroad, that is due to the men who carried the burden of taxation, the farmers, the workers and the income tax payers, and it is not due to the Minister for Finance or to the policy of the Government. This country could not go bankrupt while there is in it such an industrious community. The country could only go bankrupt if the farmers refused to do what the Minister for Agriculture asked them to do, to tighten their belts. They tightened their belts and paid up every penny demanded of them. The income tax producers also paid up when the thumb-screw was put on. For those reasons the country did not go bankrupt. We pay no tribute to the Minister for Finance, but we pay tribute to the workers, the farmers and others. We should not pay tributes to those who do not deserve them and neglect those who do. I think Deputies on the Cumann na nGaedheal Benches should not be carried away with this Budget. They know as well as I do that whatever taxation is imposed, in the long run, is going to fall on the community as a whole.

One other matter might be worthy of mention. In last year's Budget the Minister enforced a tax of £10 on travelling shops. There was a clamour amongst residents of towns a few years ago about this matter, and the Minister for Finance was urged to tax these travelling shops out of existence. As a result of that clamour a tax of £10 was imposed. During the past year there are a greater number of travelling shops than ever on the road. That has proved that the people who carry on these travelling shops are making them pay despite the tax. The amount of the tax is thus passed on to the consumer. The Minister should take some cognisance of that. It is the breakfast table of the poorest that is being taxed. If the Minister wants to collect an easy tax it is all right to continue the present arrangement, but if he wants to take the extra burden off the poor he should either increase the £10 tax to an amount that will put these shops out of existence or remit it altogether. The consumer is paying the present tax of £10, and that is an unfair burden. There has been general disappointment at the Budget, and nothing that the President, or even Deputy J.J. Byrne can say in its favour is going to fool the people.

Speaker.P: I wonder if there was ever such a scurrilous speech made in this House as the one that has been made by the Deputy who has just sat down? The Deputy adopted the unprecedented method of singling out particular Deputies, mentioning them by name and terming them windbags.

On a point of personal explanation. I quoted the Minister for Finance, who described members of local bodies as windbags, and I instanced members of local bodies on the opposite benches, and asked if the Minister specially referred to them. I did not call Deputies windbags, but if I had accidentally thought of the Deputy who has just spoken I might have done so.

My opinion of the Deputy is not very high. He is an inexperienced man, and he is presuming on his inexperience. He has presumed to attack men in this House who are old enough to be his father, and who were in politics before he was born. These attacks will only react on the Party sitting on the opposite benches. Speaking on behalf of the Cumann na nGaedheal Party, we have the greatest respect for the Chairman of our Party, Deputy Davis, and for the father of the House, Deputy T. Sheehy. Anyone who listened to the speech of Deputy Clery could only come to one conclusion, that if there was an authority in the House on what constituted a windbag that authority rested in the person of Deputy Clery.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Clery told us here about the dead-weight debt of the country. He told us about it being £15,000,000. He did not tell the House what caused that dead-weight debt. He did not refer to the statement that the President made in his opening speech today when he dealt with the abnormal items in the Budget. Will the Deputy deny that there would be no dead-weight debt only for the action of the Party to which he belongs? They were responsible for £35,000,000 of a dead-weight debt. That dead-weight debt is due to no other cause whatever but to the action of the Fianna Fáil Party.

Speaker.P: Will the Deputy say where he got his figures?
Deputy Byrne should be allowed to make his speech. Deputy Clery was not interrupted.

I listened to the Deputy without a single interruption, but when he is touched on the raw himself he cannot bear to listen to the facts. We all know what Deputy Clery is. He is one of the most scurrilous members of this House, and he is the most scurrilous Deputy on any public platform. He is a man who is no acquisition whatever to his Party nor to the country. Was there ever such nonsense uttered in the House as the nonsense to which we have just listened from Deputy Clery? The Deputy told us that the Government was giving a grant of £750,000 to the farmers in relief of rates, but that they were taking it all back again by way of an indirect tax. To quote his own words, “It is quite all right for the Government to give £750,000 in relief of the farmers and for the Cumann na nGaedheal Party to take it away again by way of taxation.” The Deputy belongs, I understand, to the teaching profession, but I never knew of a boy at school who would say that deducting £265,000 from a grant of £750,000 given by the Government wiped out the £750,000 grant. Why will not the man talk common sense? We are here to listen to commonsense and to talk commonsense and not nonsense. That is what Deputy Clery has been talking for the past half-hour, and we on these benches were sick and weary sitting listening to him talking nonsense.
The same here.

He told us that the Minister for Finance could provide £260,000 for removing Army officers last year. He did not tell the House that the provision of that money saved the taxpayers thousands of pounds. Why does not the Deputy look into facts as they exist? If that is the sort of tripe that he talks to his constituents I hope we will not have his presence here in the next Dáil.
Deputy Byrne will not be here to listen to him.

We, representing city constituencies, are beginning to get tired of hearing this doleful story that we hear so often about the farmers. Is there any nation in the world that has done more for the farming community than the Government Party in this House? Does Deputy Clery realise what the Government Party have done for the farmers?
The Cumann na nGaedheal Party.

Yes, the Cumann na nGaedheal Party has done it. I do not want you to accept me as an authority on the question. I will quote an authority that will be accepted by this House, despite the jeers of the Party on the opposite benches. In the second interim report of the Banking Commission here is the statement that was made as to what had been done for the farmers in this country: “In our opinion no country in the world, so far as we are aware, has made better provision for the farming community than the Government in the matter of direct assistance and indirect assistance to agriculture.” That is a statement made by an authority that this House will accept before the authority of the Deputy who has just sat down. If the Deputy looks at the Estimates for the coming year he will see what is revealed there. I represent a city constituency, and I am aware that the Vote for Industry and Commerce in this year is £110,000. That is the Vote which is dealing with matters which give employment to over 15,000 hands extra in the last few years. What is being given to the agricultural community in the Estimates for this year? Over one-sixth of the available income of this State has gone to the relief of agriculture. Here are the figures. Annual grants: £1,364,000 to the farming community; beet sugar subsidy, £162,000; forestry, £69,000; Land Commission, £697,000; Department of Agriculture, £596,000—making a grand total of £2,888,000 for the farming community in this country. In addition to this £2,888,000 the Government are finding £750,000 this year in relief of rates, so that in this year the Government are finding the sum of £3,638,000 for relief for agriculture for the farming community.

We have been told that the farming community are the largest contributors to taxes in this State; that they form 60 per cent. of the population of the country. What, in fact, are the returns received from the agricultural community by way of taxation? It may be news to Deputy Clery, who spilled this long, doleful story, this pitiful story, that the farmers contributed £8,000,000 and the rest of the community contributed the balance to the Exchequer. This 60 per cent. of the population got by way of return practically £15,000,000.

MainHeading.P: Speaking as one who represents the City of Dublin, I stand wholly behind the Government on this Vote. We in the cities and towns know very well the value of farming to this country. We know very well that if the agricultural community goes down the rest of the country goes down with it, but we in the cities get tired of listening to the long story that is being daily pitched by the Fianna Fáil Party. We are tired listening to their story, and especially from the particular point of view as to the distribution of the money that has been granted. The Government have taken two methods of distributing this grant; 50 per cent. in the usual way and 50 per cent. on the basis of population. I see men on the benches behind Deputy Clery who represent the agricultural community, men who know more about this question than he does, and these men really appreciate what the Government has done in passing this Vote. If Deputy Clery were honest enough to admit the fact, he knows very well that any inequality in the distribution of this money that may arise is due entirely to the basis of taxation as it exists, and no matter what Party deals with de-rating, inequalities of distribution are bound to arise.

We had a clear instance of this amongst the business community in Dublin. When we required money to forward the interests of the city the money was raised upon the rateable valuation of the business men, and every man had to contribute according to the basis of his valuation. Some had contributed £50, and others £1. What is the real logical basis upon which this money can be paid? The amount of rates for which a man is liable. I suppose Deputy Clery would want to come down to the man with the £7 15s. valuation and say to him: “We will give you £20,” because there are people receiving £20 whose valuation is greater. The Deputy referred to various places in the country and endeavoured to point out how ill-distributed this money will be when it is spent.

I do not know whether Deputy Clery represents Mayo. Mayo has been specifically dealt with by Deputy O'Connell and it has been dealt with at great length by Deputy MacEntee. The strange thing about it is that everybody who deals with Mayo has a different sum as that which the farmer will receive. Deputy MacEntee told us that the small occupiers would receive 22/3 and that the nabobs of Mayo would get £6 14s. 0d. Deputy O'Connell told us that the small farmers would get 6/6. I do not know which of them to believe. Certainly both of them cannot be correct. But there is one thing that stands out, and there is that the County of Mayo is going to get £55,000 solid cash and no empty promises, and the farmers of Mayo are too level-headed a people to refuse to accept that for what it is worth.

We were told here by the Fianna Fáil Party that they stood for a whole-hog policy of de-rating. What I want to ask the members of the front benches of Fianna Fáil is, if they stand for a whole-hog policy of de-rating, will not exactly the same inequalities in the distribution of the money arise under a whole-hog de-rating as under partial de-rating? Fianna Fáil knows as well as I do that no matter what Party distributes this money to the farming community these inequalities of distribution are bound to occur and cannot be removed. If Fianna Fáil stands for a whole-hog policy of de-rating, and they have gone to great pains to show how unevenly the distribution of the money will be, I would like to ask them to explain to the farmers, especially in the constituencies of Meath and Mayo, how this inequality of distribution is to be wiped out under whole-hog de-rating. Supposing the Fianna Fáil Party were distributing this money to-morrow and that they were in a position to give full de-rating, what would happen, for instance, in the two counties of Meath and Mayo? County Meath has 5,500 farmers and they would share under whole-hog de-rating £106,886. The average sum distributed to the farmers in Meath under a full de-rating scheme would amount to £19 per head. In the County Mayo there are 28,200 farmers. Their share would be £76,000 and would amount to £2 4s. 0d. per head. Under a scheme of full de-rating the average farmer in Mayo would get 44/- per head, while the average farmer in Meath would get £19. Yet Deputy Clery says that this is an inequitable scheme of distribution. What this House looks for is plain common sense, and if Deputy Clery does not possess plain common sense he certainly ought not to impose this nonsense that he has been endeavouring to impose upon the people.

Now we come to the great bone of the whole thing, the sum of £265,000 to be raised by a tax on sugar. The rich man's Budget! The poor man is the slave under this Budget! Deputy Clery spun a long story about the poor man. Whether the interests of the poor man are as dear to him as his own interests I have a great inclination to doubt after the speech he has made to this House. He told us here, and we have been listening to it since the debate started, that it would amount to 3/- per head of the population of the Free State, and that the cost of living was going to go up to a tremendous height. I read yesterday that the price of tea is going to be reduced by 4d. per pound, and I venture to say that when this tax is carried out to the full there will not be a single halfpenny increase in the cost of living, and there is no man with the national interests at heart who will not pay a well-merited tribute to the Minister for Finance for raising three-quarters of a million of money at such little cost to the community.

Deputy O'Connell, who certainly, in my opinion, is a fair-minded critic, told us that this would cost 3/- per head to the community. If we take the population at 3,000,000, it will amount to no such sum as 3/- per head. At the highest amount it would be only 2/- per head. So that these fine deductions of Deputy O'Connell are altogether wrong.

Speaker.P: Work it out at 2/-.

Work it out yourself. A sum raised at 3/- per head would amount to £450,000. Deputy O'Connell can check me there if he wishes. The sum that the Minister for Finance wants to raise is £265,000. Why do not Deputies, in criticising the Budget, speak fairly? They are putting another £85,000 by way of taxation on the community that the Minister for Finance is not looking for, nor ever expects to get.

MainHeading.P: I just want to say one other word before I sit down. I think I have bursted the bubble of Deputy Clery. We heard a lot of talk about the rise in the cost of living of the poor of the city. I suppose if there is any section of the community that contains more poor than any other, it is the section that I represent. I say that the people in the City of Dublin are not such fools as not to realise that the Government Party has done a great deal to cure, as far as they could, the unemployment problem that exists in this country. They further realise that the imposition of this negligible tax is for the national good and the people of the City of Dublin have never stood against the national good. When their electricity undertaking, valued at two-and-a-half million pounds, was being taken away, they did not complain. That was the contribution that Dublin gave to the national good, and they are net going to boggle over a sum of £265,000.

The Deputies who were talking about raising the cost of living want to put a tax on the loaf of the poor man. I think the party that wants to put a tax on the loaf of the poor man is not confined to Fianna Fáil. They are represented in other Parties in this House. I cannot understand why those who want to put a tax on the loaf of the poor man are raising such a hullabaloo over the raising of a sum of £265,000. The Minister has done well for the country and the country appreciates it. As the President said, he receives all the odium because he is the collector of taxes, but as a sound level-headed Northman he has done well for the country and the country appreciates him.

Speaker.P: It is nearly time that this debate was wound up when Deputies like Deputy J.J. Byrne get up and advise the farmers of this country as to what is in their interests and what is not. However, Deputies like Deputy J.J. Byrne have their privileges and I suppose they have to get leave to air their views. I venture to say that the Minister for Finance has somewhat altered his view concerning this Budget since his visit to Monaghan during the week-end. I think he has come to realise, if he did not understand it in advance, that his Budget is nothing like a popular Budget and that if he does not make some attempt to undo the damage that has been done matters will look very serious for him. The total estimated expenditure for the coming year amounts to £26,365,250. We appear to be definitely up against the position, with the Minister for Finance and the Executive Council, that there is no prospect of a reduction in taxation. There is to be no reduction in the various matters that Deputies, more particularly on this side of the House, have referred to from time to time during the past three or four years. The Army pensioners are to remain, the Civic Guard is to be maintained at its present strength or at increased strength. Salaries of more than £1,000 a year, including Ministers' salaries of £1,700 a year, are to continue. Nothing whatever can be done apparently in the line of economies.

I can understand the position of the Minister for Finance in so far as the question of the land annuities is concerned, in so far as the question of the Royal Irish Constabulary pensioners is concerned, and also as regards his surrender of our claim to over-taxation since the Act of Union when he was making his ultimate financial settlement with the representatives of the British Government. I can understand his attitude in these matters. He has been the signatory to these transactions and it would be expecting too much of him to admit that he had blundered in this matter of Ireland's finances; that he had committed the country to financial liabilities that were not embodied in the Treaty and that we are under no obligation to carry out.
[An Ceann Comhairle took the Chair.]

MainHeading.P: It would be too much to expect him to admit he had mismanaged our financial affairs in that way. I do think he must be convinced by this time that he did actually blunder. If he is so convinced, or if he has any doubt about the matter, I think the least he might do is to make way for a Minister for Finance who would endeavour to undo the financial mess into which the present administration has brought the country. We find that for an expenditure of £750,000 for the relief of the agricultural community it is actually necessary to impose fresh taxation. To my mind there is no justification for that. We have repeatedly pointed out where economies could be effected that would result in a saving of a much larger sum. I think if the Minister for Finance gave any serious consideration to the matter at all he would realise that. Of course the position may be that these people are hanging on to the Cumann na nGaedheal Government, and that they cannot shake them off. If that is the position they should make way for others, and if that is not the position there can be no justification for not effecting the necessary economies to give the miserable relief that they propose to give in this Budget.

I will remind the Minister for Finance that the demand for relief was coupled with an equally insistent demand that there would be no increase in taxation in order to provide the necessary money to give that relief. We actually find the Minister imposing a tax on an essential article of food, an article that is in universal use. This article, sugar, is consumed, perhaps, even to a greater extent in the homes of the labouring classes and small farmers than in the homes of people who can better afford to bear the burthen. When we criticise the proposed method of relief we are accused of being against de-rating. I think the President made such an accusation; other members of the House certainly did. It ought not to be necessary to reply to that, and I do not propose replying to it in detail. I will say very definitely that we are in favour of de-rating, but we are not in favour of whole-hog de-rating if it means the putting on of additional burthens of taxation in order to finance it. We do hold that the land annuities ought to be retained, the R.I.C. pensions ought to be retained, and that agricultural land ought to be completely de-rated out of these moneys.

I notice that, so far as the Press reports go, when the Minister for Finance was in Monaghan on Sunday he did not explain how his relief scheme was going to work out in the county. I am sure, though there were not many farmers represented at the meeting, they would be interested to know how this relief for rates on agricultural land was going to affect them. If my conception of how we are going to be affected in County Monaghan by this relief scheme is not correct, I would like the Minister to make any corrections that may be necessary. I do not wish to mislead anybody in the matter. It appears from the calculations I have made that Monaghan County would get £20,587. The number of holdings in Monaghan not exceeding £15 valuation is 7,714. The number of holdings exceeding £15 valuation is 4,763. The 7,714 small holders would receive between them £5,696, and the 4,763 large holders would receive between them £14,891. In other words, the 7,714 small holders would receive approximately 14s. 6d. per holding per year, and the 4,763 large holders would receive approximately £3 2s. 6d. per holding per year. These figures are approximately correct.

It must be very evident that the average-sized family on a holding in County Monaghan under £15 valuation will consume, presumably, about half-a-stone of sugar each week. Let us suppose they consume half-a-stone in the week. We find then that they will actually contribute more per year by the tax on sugar than they are going to get by way of relief of rates. The actual result in County Monaghan of this relief to the farming community is that the persons under £15 valuation, labourers and town dwellers, are being taxed for the purpose of relieving the larger holders. If you go down the valuation list below the £15 mark —down to £5 and below £5—the anomaly becomes more evident.

The Minister indicated in the Budget speech that this relief was to be made the excuse for abolishing local government for all practical purposes. We understood from the Minister that he wished to get rid of the wind-bags. I was listening to that speech and I was wondering how many of the wind-bags would be invited to meet the Minister in Monaghan. I was not a bit surprised to find that, regardless of the political views these wind-bags might be supposed to hold, they were nevertheless all welcome at the Minister's meeting.

I did not observe that he told any of them what he said about them in the Dáil. I did not notice that he mentioned that these people were only wind-bags. His attitude appears to be considerably altered towards them, and his attitude towards local government and local representatives appears to be considerably modified since he went down amongst his constituents. We do not often see him there, and if every visit would have an equally good effect on his outlook, I think it is rather a pity he does not come more often. According to the reports appearing in the daily Press on last Monday, the views of the Minister with regard to public representation appear to be considerably altered. He is reported to have said:—

Amongst other reasons why the Government had not agreed to complete de-rating was that they believed that if there was complete de-rating local government would have to be abolished, as county councils, with 90 per cent. of their revenue provided by the Exchequer, would be tempted to be extravagant. The Government, however, believed local government was a necessity. There were certain things they felt which might be better done by a central authority, but in actual practice, with the rigidity, delay and red-tape of the central authority, work would be less efficient, and they thought it better that the system of local government should be maintained. What the Government was aiming at was reform that would make the system more businesslike and efficient. If they had councils, say, of 55 members, it was going to be hard to get work done owing to the size of the council and the loquacity of members. He did not say they were going to impose on county councils the Dublin or Cork system of managerships, without modification. Obviously there would have to be modification. and the object was to give control in all essential matters to elected representatives, and only to alter the system in such a way as to get the work done expeditiously and with economy.”

That is very different to the statement made by the Minister for Finance here on the 6th May, in column 777, regarding his attitude towards local administration and local bodies. He made that statement before he went to Monaghan, and presumably before the wind-bags put a gun to his head and threatened to blow out his political brains.

If the relief which it is now proposed to give is not to be neutralised within a few years it is necessary to make substantial alterations in the system of local government which will check the tendency to fresh expenditure. In any case it has long been apparent that our present system has grave defects which militate against efficiency. Accordingly it is proposed to introduce at a very early date proposals for the reform of the county council. The work of the boards of health will be drawn into the county council, the size of which will be substantially reduced. At present even when a council has only a normal number of windbags the whole time of the meeting is frequently wasted on a few unimportant items. The consequence is that many of the men who would make the best type of local representative are increasingly unwilling to serve as members of councils. With a reduction of the number of members it is anticipated that the number of windbags on the various councils will decrease more than proportionately. It is proposed to introduce a managership system for counties somewhat similar to that in operation in Dublin and Cork. It is believed that the reforms contemplated will not only tend to prevent unjustifiable increases in expenditure but will in many cases enable sound economies to be effected.

I am glad to see that the Monaghan windbags have considerably altered the Minister's attitude towards local administration and that we are not going to have imposed on us anything like the system existing in Dublin and Cork. If, as I said at the beginning, his visit has had that effect upon him, I would be glad to see him coming oftener. There is another aspect of the sugar tax, to which I would like to draw attention. The Minister for Finance and the President appear to be badly served by the Department of External Affairs. In column 1091, on the 8th May the President stated: “The Minister mentioned that the price of sugar this year was 6/4. Two years ago it was 12/4. The imposition of this tax will leave the sugar cheaper than it was two years ago. That, however, is a matter that Deputies are anxious to forget or else to ignore.” I wonder was the President or the Minister for Finance aware of the formation of the sugar combine about which we read in the Press this week? A message from Brussels states:

“The International Agreement for limiting the export of sugar was signed yesterday by the delegates of Cuba, Java, Germany, CzechoSlovakia, Poland, Hungary and Belgium. The agreement, known as the Chadbourne Plan, applies to those countries, controlling in the aggregate 80 per cent. of the total export of sugar and nearly 50 per cent. of the world's production. It is to remain in force until September 1st, 1935. An International Committee, to be established at the Hague, will control the carrying out of the plan. Only three exporting nations of importance—Russia, the Dominican Republic, and Peru—are not parties to the agreement, and the adhesion of the two last-mentioned nations is regarded as probable. The present price of sugar is 1.25 cents a lb. In order to cover the costs of production and ensure a small profit the price will be increased to 2 cents a lb. The agreement provides for special measures to be taken to prevent non-importing countries from producing sugar surpluses and creating competition with the Chadbourne plan.”

If the Minister for Finance or the President is getting any real return from the Department of External Affairs I am sure that Deputy McGilligan would inform them in advance of this combine whose formation will, no doubt, bring about an increase in the price of sugar. It has already been increased in my part of the country by a considerable margin over the tax. I submit that that is a further reason why this essential article of diet should be left out of the Minister's purview when looking round for something to tax. If the Minister had the real interests of the poor at heart it is difficult to understand how he could find it in his heart to put a halfpenny extra on a pound of sugar and at the same time to remit the entertainment tax, which brings in £9,000; the racecourse betting tax, which brings in £25,000, and the stamp duties on capital, bringing in £5,000. It is quite true that these amounts would not be sufficient to finance a de-rating scheme, but it is difficult to see why he remits the tax on these particular classes of the community. Take, for example, the racecourse betting tax. The Minister does not affect to have any sympathy with betting, but when he relieves the tax on racecourse betting he relieves the men who can afford to go to a racecourse, spend the day there, and put their money on horses, but there is no relief for the man who cannot afford to go outside his own town, who perhaps puts a shilling on a horse with a local bookmaker. Although the amount from these three sources is only £39,000, I think that the Minister would be in a stronger position if he retained those three taxes instead of increasing the duty on sugar. The poor have not a keen interest in the three items on which the Minister gave a remission, but they have a very keen interest in the taxation of essential articles of food.

Members of this Party have been twitted by the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Agriculture because we are against this tax on sugar and stand for the protection of Irish industry. Boots, clothes and flour have been quoted as outstanding examples. Deputy Byrne complained of unfair tactics being adopted in debate, but I think that it is utterly unfair on the part of Ministers to mislead people on that particular matter. There is no parallel between a tax on sugar and a tax on boots and clothing. If we are in favour of production for Irish industry it is for the purpose of increasing employment and of enabling our industries to be built up, and of having our requirements so far as possible produced by our own people. I cannot see how a tax on sugar will increase employment or build up industry. It is not intended for that purpose, but is purely a revenue-raising tax, and can have no other effect. If we could succeed in building up new industries by protective tariffs or by a tax, as the Minister for Agriculture prefers to call it, and to use our surplus population in producing goods to meet our own requirements, and if we had two people for every one person we have now consuming home-made articles, it would be the most rapid way of relieving agriculture. You could halve the amount of taxation and produce the same amount of revenue.

I do not suppose that either the Minister for Finance or the Minister for Agriculture seriously meant that there was any comparison between the tax on sugar and a tax put on for developing industry, but they probably made the point to deceive the people. I suggest that it is scarcely fair tactics, and that it will very likely harm the future efforts either of the present Government, or of any future Government, to build up our industries. I always understood that the Minister for Finance was a protectionist, that he belonged to the Griffith school of thought, and I had at least to wait for this debate to be assured that he had changed in that respect. If he has not changed in that respect and that I have misunderstood his contribution, or that he disapproves of the attitude expressed in this matter by the Minister for Agriculture I would be very glad to hear it, because I do not wish to misrepresent him. I do complain that it was a deliberate attempt on the part of the Minister for Agriculture to create or to intensify opposition to the protectionist policy of this Party, and even to the partial protection policy of the Party on the opposite side.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Jordan Mr. S. Jordan
Speaker.P: A very noticeable thing in this debate for the last few days has been the twitting of members with statements made sometime previously either in the House or elsewhere. One of the most notable has been the pronouncement made by Deputy Byrne about the dead-weight debt when he was correcting Deputy Clery's figures in regard to the President's estimate of thirty-five millions. He said that were it not for the activities of the Party opposite that thirty-five millions would not have to be paid. I am sorry Deputy Byrne is not in the House now, but I hope when he is reading the Official Reports he will take my advice, and that every other member of Cumann na nGaedheal will do the same. It is about time that this thing was stopped, because they are only throwing dirty water on themselves. The Minister for Agriculture admitted frankly in Galway some time ago that they had no apology to offer that they started the civil war. That explains the thirty-five millions. Deputy Byrne, and other Deputies as well, should get that into their minds, and should not be throwing it over on the Fianna Fáil Party. He claims full responsibility for it, and he can pay the thirty-five millions if he likes. Since the debate was started Deputies have had to listen to this kind of talk and this kind of criticism. I think it would be much better if there was some useful criticism or some useful suggestion made in order to pull this country out of the mud and the mire in which it is at present.

MainHeading.P: My personal opinion of the Budget is that it at last shows the Executive Council and the whole Cumann na nGaedheal Party in their true light. They tell us that they want to give £750,000 for the relief of agriculture. I am of opinion that when you want to give relief there must be distress. I would like to remind the Executive Council, and the President particularly, that both in this House and outside it even in other countries, he repeatedly stated that this country was turning the corner, that it was prosperous, that there was no distress, no unemployment and that it was one of the grandest little countries in the world. If that is true and if the President is right in stating that both in America and Ireland, why do we want this £750,000 for the relief of distress? The President has made these statements repeatedly both in the House and in other countries. Every member of the Executive Council likewise has made them. As late as last Friday we had something similar from Deputy Shaw. In his contribution to the debate he stated:

The Free State is one of the few bright spots in a very dark world, and the Minister for Finance by his wise financial policy in handling the nation's finances is entitled to the thanks and gratitude of the people.
This is one of the bright spots, according to Deputy Shaw.

Speaker.P: Quite right.

Possibly the Deputy can see the bright spot, but I know there are people who cannot, and this Budget is not going to make it very bright for them. So much has been said about the Budget, and there has been so much criticism of the petrol tax and the sugar tax, that I am not going to delay the House in adding very much to these criticisms. Suffice it to say that in Galway and in the Gaeltacht area particularly people who are being asked to pay an extra halfpenny per pound on sugar are going to be the losers at the end of the year. In 75 per cent. of the cases the valuation of these people does not exceed £5. On that basis, assuming that the remission of rates would be about 3/- in the pound, they will benefit only to the extent of 15/-, and certainly they are going to spend more money on the additional sugar tax. As has been pointed out by several Deputies, the poorer people are, the larger are their families. That is a certainty, and anybody travelling through Galway or Mayo will frequently find families of six, eight, and ten. When it comes to supplying these families with sugar the expenditure will certainly be more than fifteen shillings extra in the twelve months. With a £5 valuation the relief will only amount to about fifteen shillings. It has been proved conclusively there are many valuations in these counties that are much less than £5. The Budget is no relief to these people. It is a further taxation on them.

MainHeading.P: I am not going to delay the House by covering the same ground over which other Deputies have travelled. There is, however, one suggestion I would make to the Minister, and he can put the money to whatever use he wishes. I understand that a year or two ago a request was made that a reduction should be granted in the duty on motor cars. Now that the Minister has put a tax on petrol, I would like to put this aspect of the case to him. I am sure the Minister will admit that in Southern Ireland there are at least 1,000 garages which are doing a fairly reasonable business in the motor trade. It would be reasonable to assume that in each of the garages we have at least six second-hand cars. As every Deputy in the House knows, the majority of garage owners, if a man goes in to purchase a new car, will offer him a good price for a second-hand car. He may think he is getting a decent price, but, as they say in society circles, the garage owner is getting a good whack out of the new car, so that he can afford to give the purchaser a good price for the old one. In the majority of cases the tax on these old cars is really prohibitive. As I said before, a few years ago the Minister was asked to give a reduction in that tax. He did give some concession, but whether that concession is still in existence I am not sure. If we take an average of six cars in each of these garages— the average, I agree, would be higher in the case of the cities—and that there are 1,000 decent, well-equipped garages in this State, that means that you have lying up 6,000 second-hand cars. I believe the principal reason why these cars are not running is because the tax on them is prohibitive. There is a lot of capital sunk in those garages, and I think it would only be fair that the proprietors of them should be relieved in some way. My suggestion to the Minister is that the horse-power tax on these cars up to, say, the year 1926, 1927, or 1928 should be reduced by half. If the Minister were to agree to do that, I believe he would be making it possible for these garage proprietors to sell the cars they have lying up. Incidentally, he will be making it possible for himself to get more money from the petrol tax because of the fact that the new owners would be running the cars.

At present, these second-hand cars are a white elephant. They are no use either to the Minister for Finance or to the garage proprietors. I make that suggestion to the Minister if he thinks it feasible to reduce the tax on these cars by half and thereby enable garage proprietors to put into the development of their business the capital that they have sunk in their garages. I am sure that all parties are anxious for the development of business. I think that if my suggestion were given effect to it would act as a great stimulus in the business that we are dealing with. It would result in enormous good to the country. The revenue would be considerably increased as a result of the increased number of cars on the road. It is possible, too, that some of the taxes which have been the subject of some very severe criticism in the course of this debate could be reduced. I am not going to delay the House by going over the ground already covered by a number of Deputies in respect of the petrol and sugar tax.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Blythe) Ernest Blythe
Speaker.P: In a very long debate like this a great deal that is said must consist of repetition, either with or without variation. Consequently it will not be necessary for me to go over in great detail the arguments that have been used. Deputy Davin said that there was no substantial difference between the Fianna Fáil proposal in regard to de-rating and the proposal the Government have laid before the House. There was a difference in allocation, a difference which will be definitely to the advantage of the poorer districts because the allocation proposed in the Fianna Fáil motion was one which took no account in any way of the needs of the counties as distinct from one another. The proposal that we have made will definitely give a bigger allocation to those areas which are poor and which have the larger population. It is impossible, by any system of de-rating, to assist people in proportion to their needs, because those that are the more needy, if you like, pay the smallest proportion of rates and consequently can only be relieved to that extent. If Deputies had all the interests in those who are the poorer amongst the farmers that they allege they have, and a special interest in the poorer farmers, they would not lend their support to a claim for de-rating at all. They would recognise that it is only beyond a certain level of wealth that substantial help can be given to any farmer through de-rating.

As to the suggestion that has been made that de-rating ought to have been by way of total relief on the small valuations, there is at once this objection to that proposal. If you are going to relieve all farmers below £15 valuation, as has been suggested, from rates, that means that you are going to relieve the land of two-thirds of the farmers of the country from rates. That, I believe, almost as much as complete de-rating, would involve the abolition of local government as we now know it. Undoubtedly we have at present amongst the local government voters a considerable number of people who are not liable to any appreciable extent for rates. If you were to add something like two-thirds of the farmers of the country to those who would have no liability for rates, then obviously you cannot carry on local government as it is at present. At any rate, if you are to carry on local government in its present form it would mean a change in the franchise, a change which would substantially alter the real character of local government even if you maintained to some extent the outward forms. At any rate, it would be utterly impossible to carry on local government as we now have it with efficiency or with any regard to economy if you are going to relieve such a large proportion of the people altogether from the payment of rates. One of the choices that has to be made in connection with de-rating is that local government in its present form must be sacrificed if you go in for total de-rating, either of the whole of the farming community or some substantial section of it.

MainHeading.P: One of the salient features in the reports of the De-rating Commission was the importance that was attached to the maintenance of local government. I personally think that local government control by elected representatives of the people in the various counties is necessary, and that a great many things which theoretically might be better done by the Central Government in reality and practice would not be so well done because of rigidity, delays and the impossibility of varying administration to suit local conditions. I therefore rule out altogether the proposal that has been put forward, that a certain substantial proportion of the farmers should be relieved completely of rates. As a matter of fact the Deputies who have been arguing to do that argued against the method of de-rating altogether so far as these people are concerned. There is considerable inconsistency in their arguments in that respect.

It has been alleged that a very large proportion of the grant of £750,000 would be taken back from the farmer by way of the sugar tax. Undoubtedly some proportion of the grant will be taken back by way of the sugar tax, and also some small proportion of the amount raised by the petrol tax. But the estimates given of the extra amount that will be thrown on the small farmer's family have been ridiculously exaggerated. If we leave out of account the sugar used in the manufacture of sweets and in jam factories, the total consumption per family of sugar would not give as high an average for the halfpenny tax as 15/-. It would not give an average beyond 12/6. There is no doubt that the small farmer's family does not use the average amount of sugar. The small farmer's family uses sugar practically for tea only. In the better-off household there is jam-making, there is the manufacture of puddings and cakes, and there is considerably more sugar used there than in the small farmer's family. I admit it is extremely difficult to get the average, unless one examines the household accounts or the grocers' accounts over a large number of cases, and it would be extremely difficult to say what the small farmer with £5 or £10 valuation consumes in sugar in the year. But suppose the war-time ration of half a pound of sugar per person were taken each week. Suppose we say that to the average family of that sort the consumption would be three-quarters of a pound, which would be 50 per cent. more than the war-time consumption, the extra cost would be very little more than half the figure of 15/- which Deputies mentioned as a result of the new taxation.

On the other hand, just as all the figures we have heard with regard to the charges that will be thrown upon the small farmer's family by a halfpenny tax on sugar have been grotesquely exaggerated, so all the benefits of de-rating for the small farmer have been minimised. There are counties in which as a result of the new grant the farmer with £10 valuation, for instance, will get 36/-. In a county where a farmer might get 36/- as a result of the distribution of the new grant if he had a £10 valuation, then the farmer with £2 10s. Od. holding will get 9/-, and even that particular farmer, in my opinion, will be better off, because I think, for the farmer of that size, the estimate of 7/6 extra to be paid as a result of the sugar tax is an over-estimate. Probably 5/- or 6/- would be much nearer than 7/6. But there is no use in Deputies suggesting that we could get results out of de-rating which cannot possibly be got out of it. If Deputies do refuse to have regard to the question of production, and other aspects of de-rating, and concentrate solely on the question of burden, then they ought to make up their minds that de-rating in any form is a thing they should not stand for.

We cannot deal with the question of taxation merely on the basis of popularity or merely on the basis of burden, although burden has to be taken into account and is an important matter always. But you cannot base your taxation proposals on that, because if we want the country to get on and to get rid of the evils which do exist in the economic system, we must look, not to what people will feel about it, and not merely to the inconvenience that people may experience as a result of taxation, but to the question of production. It would be very easy to levy a certain tax which would be popular and easy to carry out, and which would seem in the first instance not to injure the poorer members of the community very much, but which would, in fact, injure those members of the community very seriously by checking production and stiffing business enterprise. Under the system that exists here and in most other countries, it is the duty of the Government, and it is recognised by Governments of all countries—even those of the most left-wing tendency—to have regard to the question of production, to encourage an increase in production so far as they can, or, at any rate, to try to avoid steps that would cause a decrease in production.

There is no tax at all that is going to leave unaffected any section of the community. Even taxes that cannot visibly be passed on, and which theoretically are not passed on, affect other members of the community and the poorer members of the community. Any tax that is taken into the Exchequer must lessen the resources of the people from whom it is taken; it must lessen the employment given by them, and in very many cases a tax that would seem hardly to be passed on at all would inflict as much injury on the working community as a tax that seems to be passed on. The real moral in respect of that is that for anything like this question of de-rating, both sides have to be taken into account, and we have frankly to weigh it up, recognising that the imposition of new taxation is an evil, and we have to see whether the psychological and other effects of giving de-rating are going to counterbalance that. I hold that the giving of relief to agriculture, and to ease the financial position of agriculture, is not radically different from giving protection to a manufacturer to enable him to carry on his business with greater ease.
Deputy Murphy asked me for some detailed figures of the spirit revenue. I shall send them to him, but I have not got them at hand at the moment.

Several Deputies talked about taking the tax off racecourse betting. A Committee sat on that on which Parties on all sides of the House were represented, and that Committee some time ago unanimously recommended that course. I do not think, therefore, that the proposal to remit that tax can be looked upon as entirely a Government proposition. It is a proposition that appears to have support elsewhere throughout the House. I explained the reason for giving it, and the circumstances in which it was given, and I really do not think that I need add to that at all. Whatever burdens are placed either on those who are not interested in agriculture or on smaller agriculturists by taxation that is necessary for the purpose of giving de-rating would be increased in proportion as the money expended on de-rating was increased. If there had been a substantially larger sum voted, then the difficulty of raising the money would be increased, and the burden on the various people would have to be increased. Now there is no doubt that directly the urban population gets nothing from it, but if there is any improvement in agricultural production as a result of this measure of relief, then some of that will come through the urban population. It is a fact also that the various protective measures which have been carried have given direct assistance to the urban population, and have been of no direct assistance to the agricultural population.
I think that in all the circumstances and having regard to the slump in prices which has occurred, this contribution towards assisting the agriculturists is quite fair and is quite justifiable.

There has been a certain amount of discussion about the general Budgetary position. I think that has been sufficiently dealt with by other speakers. A very large proportion of the costs of the Civil War, both the costs in respect to compensation and the military costs, has been paid out of revenue. The taxpayer contributed quite substantial sums in the earlier years which might reasonably have been borrowed. There has only been a very trivial increase in the dead-weight burden of national debt in recent years arising out of any sort of cash transactions. Even last year, as I pointed out, there would have been no increase in national debt except for one or two transactions, one of which at least placed no extra burden on the State as a whole but rather reduced the burden on the taxpayer although increasing the nominal total of national debt. The operation of the Land Act, which has recently been passed, and the activities which will be carried out under that will, during the present financial year, lead to a very substantial increase in the dead-weight burden of debt, but at the end of the year this particular spurt in connection with land operations will have come to an end, and while there will be still need to issue bonds to a certain extent under the Land Acts from 1923 down to the present date, those amounts will be small.

On the other hand, items of expenditure for which we have been borrowing will come to an end, and if the present Budgetary policy remains absolutely unchanged there will begin to be an actual reduction of the present relatively small dead-weight burden of national debt. Our position in that respect is immensely superior to the position in most other countries and our real position is reflected in the credit of the State. The people who have to lend money—at any rate some of them—examine very carefully our estimates and accounts. I discovered myself, when we were issuing the Second National Loan, part of which was floated in America, that the representatives of American banks with whom we were dealing had examined every item of our accounts with the greatest detail. As a matter of fact they knew the accounts better than, say, the Deputies who criticise on the opposite side. Having carried out that examination and being aware of the facts they were prepared to put our loan on the market on terms which were very favourable.

Deputies need not try to go behind what is the general verdict in regard to what is our financial position. It would be really more useful both from the point of view of the House, and from the point of view of the country, if they were not to regard it as a duty to try to paint things black. We have our difficulties and there is no use whatever, no benefits either to the Party that does it, or to the country as a whole, in attempting to blacken the financial position of the country.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J.X. Murphy Mr. J.X. Murphy

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr. Bourke) James A Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr. Bourke)
Speaker.P: I assume that with the permission of the Dáil I will continue the usual practice of taking Vote 10 (Office of Public Works) and Vote 11 (Public Works and Buildings) together, as they cover practically the same ground. On Vote 10 not many points require notice. It will be observed that there is a small increase on sub-head A—Salaries, Wages, and Allowances—and if the details are examined it will be seen that this is due in the main to three items—an improvement in the scale of pay of temporary engineers engaged for arterial drainage work, the addition of a temporary draughtsman to the engineer's branch, and the addition of six temporary junior architectural assistants in the architectural drawing office. The first of these points, the improvement in the pay of temporary engineers engaged for arterial drainage, has been for some time pressed upon us by representatives of the engineering profession, and was once or twice raised in this House. The scale of pay has been somewhat improved—the maximum raised from £250 to £350—in order to give a little inducement to these young engineers to stay at this job for a few years when they have got the experience which makes them useful. The engineering draughtsman and the six temporary architectural assistants who are being added to the staff are required for the various new works we are undertaking. These works are shown in Vote 11.

Sub-head B—Travelling Expenses— shows a small decrease on the whole, but it includes a new item for travelling expenses of the National Monuments Advisory Council. This Council was appointed under the National Monuments Act, 1930, Section 21; it held its first meeting on the 10th September last, and has already shown itself a very active and energetic body. It has produced proposals for a general archaeological survey of the national monuments of Ireland, which are now under consideration by the Minister for Finance. These are all the points I think it necessary to mention on Vote 10.

In Vote 11, sub-head A—Purchase of Sites and Buildings. It continues to be necessary to purchase sites and buildings for housing the Gárda Síochána, for the new Preparatory Colleges, and for other purposes, but we hope to be able to reduce the expense a little this year.

MainHeading.P: Sub-head AA—Annuities. As explained on previous occasions, this is an annuity in repayment of an advance for the purchase of the site of the College of Science and Government Buildings, and the erection of the college; it comes to an end in 1933.

Sub-head B—New Works. There are some points of special interest here. The new works on the Oireachtas buildings may interest Deputies. The extension of hot-water heating is a small matter of economy; it will nearly supersede the use of coal fires in the offices, and will secure the rooms from deterioration when unoccupied. The heading “New Restaurant, Members' Rooms, etc.,” refers to a connected series of works for improving the accommodation for members. The part to be begun in 1931-2 is the erection of a two-storey building facing Kildare Place, of which the principal purpose is to provide rooms for the Opposition members. Work No. 4—renewal of statues on the Dublin Custom House—is a small matter in money, but will, we hope, have a considerable effect in restoring the appearance of the building to what it was before it was burned. There were formerly four statues on the roof facing the river; they were so badly damaged by the fire that they had to be removed, and the front looks rather flat without them. Work No. 11—reconstruction of the Four Courts. We were somewhat delayed by the unfortunate dispute in the Dublin building trade, and it is doubtful if we shall be able to finish the work, as we expected, in time to move the courts in during the long vacation.

Now as to the barracks for the Gárda Síochána, Works Nos. 17 to 101. The form in which the Estimates are drawn up to meet the requirements of this House, showing every individual new work separately, makes it rather hard to see the general position. As I explained last year (on 8th May, 1930, col. 1555 of the Report), there was a partial suspension of work on these barracks in 1929-30 for the sake of economy. Any stoppage of that kind has far-reaching effects. When you are dealing with a great number of comparatively small buildings you must keep on continuously finding sites, negotiating with landlords, preparing plans, etc., etc., unless you wish to have great delay. The consequence of the stoppage in 1929-30 was that we have only been able to spend £30,000 in 1930-31. In the coming year, 1931-32, we hope to get into something like full swing again and spend £58,000. It is very desirable to get this business of housing the Gárda finished so far as it ever can be finished—that is, to provide a reasonably satisfactory barrack in every station. There are over 800 stations outside Dublin. Dublin is a separate matter. The first problem was to find a barrack of any kind in each station; that was substantially done by 1925, but many of the barracks were wretched places, fit only for temporary use. Since then we have been building, buying, renting, and adapting houses, and we have got rid of most of the worst barracks, but there are still some bad ones, and a good many more cases in which a better barrack is desirable. It will probably take three or four years more to finish the job.

Work No. 102—Grants for National Schools. This is an important part of our duties. The sum provided for grants is the same as last year, and the work of building and improving schools is going on at a good pace.

Works No. 105 to 110—Preparatory Colleges. These are large and important buildings. It will be observed that Coláiste Brighde at Ballyconnell, Co. Donegal, is nearly finished. Some additional work will be necessary in order to improve the water supply. It is occupied. Coláiste Einne, at Furbough, Co. Galway, is hardly begun, as the vendor of the land has so far failed to get a satisfactory title on which we can safely build. Coláiste Ide, Dingle, Co. Kerry, is finished and occupied. Coláiste Muire, Tourmakeady, Co. Mayo, is occupied, though there is some work still to do, mainly in the grounds. Work will, we hope, begin in 1931-32 on the new preparatory college at Ballyvourney in Co. Cork, and on the preparatory college to be made by adaptation of part of the buildings of the former Hibernian Military School in the Phoenix Park. There is also a larger undertaking, the new training college at Galway, already sanctioned by the Dáil; we secured the site during 1930-31, and hope to begin building in 1931-32.

Passing on to the Department of Posts and Telegraphs, Work No. 127, the completion of the General Post Office in Dublin was delayed by the building trade dispute, but is now proceeding. Work No. 129 is important. There is only a token Vote for it, because we do not expect to get to work this year, as a great deal of planning and preparation will be necessary. The proposal is to erect in Pearse Street, adjacent to Westland Row Station, a large building in which letter-sorting, parcel-sorting, and, I believe, other services can be concentrated, with considerable consequent economy in the working of the postal service.

Work No. 137—the erection of the high-power wireless station—is important. We are at present engaged in finding a site. For the Department of Defence we hope to finish the work proposed at Baldonnel Aerodrome. It was delayed by the building trades dispute. We are continuing the restoration of the Michael Collins Barracks at Cork (Work No. 142) for the rather large force of reserve battalions and permanent staff stationed there. The items for which this year's Vote provides are (a) quarters for unmarried officers, (b) mess and canteen for sergeants, and (c) district offices. The two items for dining halls and food stores, etc., at Kilbride and Kilworth rifle ranges (Works Nos. 143 and 144) are very necessary, if the troops are to take full advantage of the facilities for rifle practice in those rather remote and inaccessible places.

I think no other new work calls for special notice, nor do I wish to make any observation on any other sub-heads of the Vote except those for drainage maintenance and arterial drainage— Sub-heads J (1), (2), (3) and (4). Sub-head J (1)—Drainage Maintenance— shows a decrease to £1,000. It is not expected that any fresh scheme of restoration will be undertaken in the year 1931-32. The estimate of £1,000 is for expenses of charging orders, etc., in districts already completed. Sub-head J (2)—Arterial Drainage— shows an increase of £7,000, indicating that we expect to do a little more work and spend a little more money in 1931 than in 1930. The provision represents, of course, only the free grants by the Government. I went pretty fully into this matter of arterial drainage last year (8th May, 1930, cols. 1558-1565 of the Report), and gave a great number of figures. I do not propose to go over them again, but I will give those relating to schemes actually submitted to the occupiers for their votes. I stated in May, 1930, that up to that time 46 schemes had been submitted to occupiers of land; the corresponding figure is now 57. The number of schemes accepted by the votes of the occupiers was then 32; it is now 42. The number of schemes on which actual work on the lands had begun was then 18; it is now 24. The number of schemes in which the works were finished was then 5; it is now 18. These few figures indicate the steady progress of the work.

As regards the Barrow drainage, sub-head J (3), as I explained last year, the small Vote of £5,000 for the Barrow does not by any means represent the amount of work to be done; we expect to spend some £48,000, but most of this will be loan money, and will be charged to Vote 8—Local Loans. The scheme is going on well, and will, we expect, be concluded in about three years from now.

The estimate of £5,000 is for the free grant only; the total estimate for the year is £48,000, of which £43,000 will be provided from the Local Loans Fund (Vote 8), and £5,000 on this Vote. The expenditure during 1930-31 was £62,000. The lesser expenditure anticipated during 1931-32 is not because we expect to do less excavation, but because we expect to do it more cheaply, and the reason of this is that a smaller part of it will be on the Lower Barrow (between Athy and Monasterevan), where the bottom is hard and the river large, and a greater part on the Upper Barrow and the tributaries, where the work is easier, and, therefore, cheaper per cube yard excavated.

During the year ending 31/3/'31 an output of 588,616 cubic yards of soft and rock excavation has been effected, bringing the excavation total for the year practically to the equal of all previous output. The greater part of the excavation of the main river has now been done, and excavation has been begun and has progressed well on the following tributaries:—The Finnery River, the Stradbally River, the Figile River, the Upper Barrow.
In addition, under-pinning and repairs have been carried out to the Town Bridge and Spa Lane Bridge, Portarlington, and some smaller bridges.

The total expenditure on the work up to 31st March, 1931, was £289,000. Owing to the operations of the mechanical excavators, eleven of which are employed, the unit costs of the excavation are kept low. They vary in different circumstances, but a great deal of work is now being done at 1/3 per cube yard.
